reviewText: Today every ethnic group out there has stood up for their rights not to be movie villains. Every group that is, except for the much maligned rednecks. Add to that a worldwide distrust of anybody who thinks it's a good idea to vote for Bush (twice) and suddenly people from the American South are the reigning monsters of horror cinema. But this one was from 1974, so it was ahead of its time in that respect. The plot (like a film called "Texas Chain Saw massacre" needs a plot) involves your typical band of merry idiots (this group stands out for the inclusion on a wheelchair bound lad) driving around Texas when they stumble into the wrong neck of the woods. From there this story takes a turn for the worse. Our friends are slaughtered one by one until only one is left, and wouldn't you know it she's a shapely blond. Director Tobe Hooper brings a razor's edge to this film as we get to watch as he walks that fine line between fetishistic exploration and run of the mill horror movie torture. We're happy to go along because we can't look away, and that feeling remains throughout the film. It comes to be about a society that is sick and diseased. A blood-sucking (literally) grandpa, a hyperactive hitchhiker with a taste for his own blood, and Leatherface who comes off as just another member of the family. Above all this is a family of sportsmen, they hunt for sport and prefer their game to walk on two legs.There is an overriding theme of slaughter that runs through this film, be it animals or humans. In the opening scene the characters naively discuss the best way to kill cattle. They throw words like "humanely" around, but they seem anything but later on when these same tactics (meat hooks, chainsaws) are used on them. For those of us who are carnivores we know that we end life for our dinner. We make up stories, like how humanely we end that life, to make ourselves feel better, but this film chops those lies into pieces. This film has much more in common with the recent films of Rob Zombie than it does with the current remake and sequel. It takes its twisted nature and beats you over the head with it. The more disgusted you are the better job Hooper has done. So for those of you who like your films screwed up on every possible level this is the film for you. It doesn't have the modern trappings of today's horror films such as irony and camera winking, it isn't even all that sensational. The kills are somewhat muted by reality. The documentary style means no extreme close ups of the gore or anything of that nature. To add gloss would be to hinder its cause, it's disturbing because it seems real. The image of the South that they present is pretty much exactly what I think of when I think of Bush Country. I think decay and isolation and people who aren't all that sophisticated. They got gas stations but they ain't got no gas. The real horror Leatherface and Co. have perpetrated against America in recent years has happened at the voting booth, but for that horror flick I would suggest "So Goes the Nation." For a more cinematic look at the wrath of the South I recommend this film, though only barely. ***1/4

reviewText: "The Texas Chain Saw Massacre", the 1974 original by Tobe Hooper, is one of my absolute favorite films. It has a certain atmosphere and visual style/cinematographic brilliance that in my opinion is only matched in the horror field by John Carpenter's "The Thing", Sam Raimi's "The Evil Dead", and Dario Argento's "Suspiria". It's an absolute treat to the senses (visually, aurally) for those fascinated by the macabre.The best way to see the film (besides watching a film print) is to watch the UK Seriously Ultimate Edition Blu-ray (BD) released by Second Sight. I'm unsure if it is region-free, but it does play on Region A players, and can be ordered from Amazon's UK site. Note, however, that there are standard definition extras that are in the PAL format, which won't play unless your TV handles it. (Most HDTVs sold in the US do not, a most frustrating restriction imposed by the manufacturers and perhaps by movie and TV show distributors as well.)I own and have watched both versions, and the reason I say the UK BD is better than the US BD released by Dark Sky Films is simple: detail. Both are sourced from the same restoration and HD master handled/supervised by Synapse Films' Don May, Jr.; however, the US release suffers from serious digital noise reduction. There is little grain to speak of, and the removal of grain results in a very soft, murky appearance. It's not an altogether dreadful presentation, but does not do the film's 16mm roots justice.The UK BD shows quite a lot of rough film grain, and the rest of the details in the image are intact as well. Mind you, it IS a rather soft film, and shot on 16mm in the early to mid '70s, so don't expect super refined detail--but there is a lot there to be seen that which is handled properly with the UK disc and not so much the US one.Light is handled properly with the UK disc as well. Whether the source be the sun or a lightbulb, light looks very natural and radiant on this release, giving off a natural glow, whereas on the US disc it looks flat and dull. Regarding light and dark contrast, the UK disc also looks sufficiently dark when needed (shaded areas, night scenes, and shadows), and appropriately bright during daytime scenes and indoors, while the US release is a little weak in this regard.There is an issue of difference in coloring. The color timing on the UK disc I find overall to be much deeper and warmer. The reds are generally a bit more orange-red than on the US disc, but I find the reds and all other colors more accurate to a low-budget 16mm film shot in 1973 (it was filmed during the summer of that year). You can see full resolution screencap comparisons between the two releases, as well as between the US and Austrian BDs, at Caps-a-Holic. Note that the Austrian release looks very similar to the US release, but has more detail and is brighter. I'd like to buy this one eventually, but it is of course expensive to import, is a limited edition, and is Region B-locked. (Eventually I intend on getting a Region B Blu-ray player to take advantage of the great Region B-locked BDs released in the UK and other parts of Europe, but not for some time.) Regardless, based on the screencaps, I find the UK release to be far more visually pleasing than the Austrian one and is likely more accurate to the film and HD sources. The Austrian release appears too bright with not as rich of contrast as the UK release, and detail seems more present on the UK release as well.So, if you want my recommendation, I say skip the US Dark Sky Blu-ray of this film, and get the UK Second Sight Blu-ray instead (you can order it from Amazon.co.uk). It's a far greater visual presentation than what's available here; and again, it WILL play on a Region A Blu-ray player. Just bear in mind that all of the extras are in standard definition PAL format, so they won't do you any good unless your TV and BD player are capable of handling the video signal. The UK BD is truly a treat, and contains original mono, 2.0 PCM lossless, and 5.1 DTS audio tracks. Highly recommended for fans of this horror film masterpiece and for true high definition enthusiasts.As for the US release, I give it three stars. It's not an awful transfer, and all the extras are of course playable in the US. However, since seeing the UK release, I never intend on watching the US one again in regard to the main feature.

reviewText: The Tobe Hooper classic is not nearly the gore-fest many remember it to be, but that doesn't mean it's not a gruesome, sadistic and brutal low budget film.The very idea of a family of nearly retarded, essentially unstoppable cannibal psycho killers is scary stuff.  Since you know it was inspired by the real life Wisconsin's Ed Gein it's a little more disturbing yet.  The fact that nearly all of the young characters we meet are as annoying and whiny as those in the Blair Witch Project, might dilute the horror of what happens to them for some of you, but some of the images, and motifs that Tobe Hooper finds are at times nightmarish and disturbing. The fat guy annoys, Marilyn screams and screams again, and there is that meat hook conversation stopper.  It's sick, twisted stuff and the low budget amateurism of the film adds to its dark grisliness. You won't get the gore effects, but you'll get plenty to be squeamish about ( Nuff said I hope).  The DvD offers probably the best print you'll ever see of the film. It's far from perfect but it was shot on cheap film stock by people who were learning how to shoot films.Okay there's no barbecue sauce but there are some some valuable extras including an informative and worth listening to commentary track, too brief blooper reel and trailers for all the sequels.Christopher J. Jarmick, Author of The Glass Cocoon with Serena F. Holder...
summary: Hoopers Classic Now with Barbecue Sauce.

reviewText: Awhile ago I was having a conversation with someone about musical tastes where we vastly disagreed on what was simply awesome bands and which ones were purely based around taste, such as people who love R&B; and Rap to people who prefer Dance. In a way, Texas Chainsaw Massacre, as well as the Exorcist and the Shining are like the Beatles and Led Zeppelin of horror movies: you must love them and say anything different and you're going to get lynched. So I will agree that the film is definately refreshing considering the latest crop of so-called "horror movies", yet at the same time I wonder why it didn't hit me that much.5 kids are travelling through the country and hear of a couple of houses. They decide to check it out only no one's home...seemingly at first. Pretty soon they meet Leatherface, a man in a burlap sac mask who wields a big fat chainsaw. Pretty soon, the kids start going one by one and we find a family seriously depraved and having to escape alive. It's odd how I can't say any more about the plot; not because of spoilers but because there's not a lot else to say.Like many a filmgoer, I can't stand the latest releases in horror. Instead of using atmosphere, pacing and mood to creep people out, they go for broke and show some of the more violent scenes. This film isn't even gory at all. In fact, the film's goriest scene, where one of the kids meets a chainsaw, isn't even shown onscreen. Your mind fills in what went on which can probably be even more disturbing. Adding to the realism is that it's shot in a kind of documentary-like style. One problem I had with the film was that the dread didn't feel there. There was pre-MTV style editing and extreme-closeups of eyeballs and maybe I've just seen it before but it didn't creep me out like it should've(and having a woman scream for 20 minutes doesn't help).If I saw this in 1974, I mostly likely would've been creeped out of my wits but seeing it 32 years later, it's more like "yeah it was alright although I better not say so cause then everybody will bug me about it". If you're a fan, go ahead and buy it because it's probably the best release of the film but personally, I'm not.
summary: It's not THAT scary but it was enjoyable

reviewText: When I was very little my uncle from the city would visit and always tell us about TCM.  So I, of course, developed a near obsession about it.  When I finally saw the film it WAS as scary as he had told.  When I got to college I did a paper about it where some research was required.  First of all people must consider the times.  The Manson case had only recently been settled and people were still affected and freaked by it.  It is no accident that the lead looks so much like the beautiful Sharon Tate (a freaksih side note is that this actress, Marilyn Burns, also played one of Manson's women in the TV miniseries: Helter Skelter).  What some don't realize about the Manson case is that fear was as much a part of the murders as actual death was.  This movie plays that out like no other movie, except possibly Last House on the Left, when the camera seemingly lingers on Sally as she screams so affectingly (a great performance) after all her companions have been killed.  As so many others have already pointed out, it is this documentary feel that makes it so amazing.  It does of course have elements of the Ed Gein case which so many state but, as other films of these years, the Manson murders were key because they were more recent and imprinted in the minds of so many americans as a most brutal act.  These were mostly cautionary tales, especially Last House (which I personally cannot see as a Horror film since all fun is out the door, it's actually too emotionally effecting) whereas Massacre while hard to watch had a sense of fun which horror has to have.
summary: Simply thee most frightening of all horror films

reviewerName: Damian Gunn "The Dark One is I"
reviewText: In 1974 Tobe Hooper released a film that will go down as one of the greatest horror films of all time.  Now, I've seen the remake, and loved it.  I had never seen the original despite the fact that all of my friends insisted that I do...so finally I gave in and watched it this morning.  I have to say that, even though I watched this film in broad daylight I was still chilled.The story, loosly based on the actual murders of Ed Gein, revolves around a group of friends, Sally, her boyfriend Gary, her disabled brother Franklin, her friend Pam and her boyfriend Kirk, as they travel to visit the gravesite for Sally and Franklins grandfather.  The gravesite has been the object of some scandle as bodies have been dug up and ritualistically tampered with.  The opening scenes of this film are photo's of a corpse that's wired to a gravestone.  It's haunting to say the least.Upon seeing the grave this group inadvertantly picks up a hitch-hiker, a somewhat diranged man who takes their picture, then burns it, cuts himself with a knife and then does the same to Franklin before the group tosses him from the van.  The entire group is shooken up by this intruder, but none moreso than Franklin who is convinced that something worse is going to happen.  The group decides to visit an old home owned by Sally and Frank's father, but it's what happens after they visit the home that will make your skin crawl.  Behind the house is another home, the home inhabited by cannibals who attack and torture these kids for the remainder of the film.Hooper created a cinimatic masterpiece, a disturbing, documentary type horror film that is almost as scary visually as it is subject-wise.  While concidered a soft-R to todays standards (meaning there's not a single cuss word and the gore is very light, more implied than really shown...except towards the end) it delivers some of the scariest sequences in cinema even today.  The remake changes the story quite a bit, and I believe that to be a good thing for it helps save it from being a cheap knock-off.  The remake has it's own scares and it's own thrills and doesn't rob anything off of this film but creates it's own horrific tale.So, there are those who prefer this version and those that prefer the 2003 version...either way both are great, but remember that this is where it started and this is a base for so many succesfull horror films today for it's a perfect mix of horror, inteligence and humor.  The final 30 minutes or so of this film are so insanely scary that, as I mentioned, even while watching in daylight I was shivering.  And the dinner scene is as intense and disturbing as a scene can get.If you haven't seen this film but have seen the remake and are afraid, as I was, that older horror films just can't cut it compaired to the polished horror films of today I urge you to reconcider and watch this film.  It's not like most horror films of the 70's, 80's and 90's.  It's smart, chilling and brutal and I promise you it will chill you to the bones.  I won't say which version is better for I believe they both exceed most horror films out there today and they both deliver an effective scare while bringing something new, fresh and entirly different to the table.  It's the rare instance where a brilliant film gets a brilliant remake...

reviewText: When I was a kid, The Texas Chainsaw Massacre was one of those pictures that every kid talked about, but none of us had actually seen. I always knew that after all the hype, when I finally saw it, it'd probably be a letdown. I couldn't have been more wrong...Chainsaw follows a familiar plotline- The group of teens being picked off by a maniacal killer. The similarities end there, because A)- Chainsaw was one of the first movies to use that plot, and B)- It's actually a great movie, something very few of it's successors could claim. The movie has a cheap, dirty feel to it, and it achieves an almost documentary realism, something I've never seen done so well. Despite the fact that there isn't much actual on-screen gore (In the commentary, Director Tobe Hooper reveals he was trying for a PG rating!), this remains the most disturbing film I've ever seen. It almost feels like you're watching it happen in front of you. The acting is better than you'd expect, and the characters of Leatherface, The Cook, The Hitch-Hiker, and Grandpa will stick with you for a long time. Hooper and Writer Kim Henkel have created a truly chilling mythology, and the Family's obsession with "The Meat" is REALLY scary.The DVD contains a nice widescreen transfer, commentary by Director Hooper, Gunnar "Leatherface" Hansen, and Cinematographer Daniel Pearl, trailers and TV spots for all of the Chainsaw films, deleted scenes and bloopers, a still gallery, poster and product gallery, and a spot about the props and sets. Great extras, but it'd be worth buying just for the film: It's a classic!
summary: One Of The All-Time Best Horror Movies, Period.

reviewText: Son of Sam,Ted Bundey,John Wayne Gacey,Ed Guinn.These were the people that put fear into the lives of everyone around them.A few years after the Charles Manson murders,A film that I considered a wake up call to horror films came out of nowhere.Shot in documentary film style,"The Texas Chainsaw Massacre" was the kind of film I would look up to as the kind of horror film that shouldn't be or couldn't be ignored.A group of young people,traveling through the back roads of Texas fall into complete terror when they are terrorized by a group of cannibals.The main psycho is a man named Leatherface who wears a mask made out of someone elses face,weilding a chainsaw making meat out of human prey.The rest of his family are even more psychotic.Each of the main characters(the victims)are each treated in such ways of complete terrifying situations,that reality for one of them loses it's grip.Marilyn Burns,the female lead is Sally.A victim that probably will have a pretty disturbed life after the events that takes place in this film.The actress herself was probably disturbed making this film."The Texas Chainsaw Massacre" is not a horror film to disturb just because it is a horror film.Some of these events happen.Something that even disturbs me.Tobe Hooper enters our heads reminding us that the world we live in is packed with very disturbing events.With "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre" I would rate this one of the best horror classics of the 1970s.
summary: Graphically done with such disturbance.A classic.

reviewText: It is fair to say that Tobe Hopper's 1974 version of "Texas Chain Saw Massacre" is not as well done and spooky as the 2003 remake, but you have to give credit where credit is due. "Texas Chian Saw Massacre" (yes, it was originally spelled like 'Chain Saw') is horrifying view into the American culture that truly terrified a nation, and even had some partial inspiration of horror films to appear later on, such as "House of 1000 Corpses" and "Wrong Turn." But this movie is not well acted, and some of the actors are almost laughable. The story revolves around five friends traveling though the Texas backwoods and while exploring a deceased family member's house, they are each attacked by a Chiansaw weilding maniac named Leatherface (Gunner Hansen). Each of the friends are killed brutally, even though we can't see, but it still effects us psychologically. One woman is impaled with a hook, one guy's rist is slit, another gets a hammer in the head, another gets a chainsaw in the stomach, and another has to endure a cannibalistic dinner party. ALthough the film is known for its nerve racking ending, the real scary scene comes from the scene where Pam (Terri McMinn) first enters the house where Leatherface waits and she stumbles into a room filled with human and animal corpses alike. This part of the movie is not only extremely well done in its sense to terrify you, but it is the only scene in the movie that makes you feel like you're actually there- and that's a sign of a great movie making deal.Even though it's a chilling movie, "Texas Chain Saw Massacre" is a sadistic and horrific deal that is hard to sit through. There is no battle of good versus evil, and no one to cheer for. You know it cannot end well, and all the film really does is show a group of kind, everyday people getting butchered by a family of inbred killers. I wouldn't recommend this movie over its remake, just because the remake has better acting and you know that its just a movie, plus you are routing for the characters to live. I do, however, think that Tobe Hopper's "Chainsaw" and the remake are the only ones in the series to watch, for the others are just plain old movie crap. So if you want to get creeped out and put in a seriously depressed and disturbed mood, rent "Texas Chain Saw Massacre," the movie that really puts a bad name in for Texas.
summary: A Great Film For What It Had to Work With

reviewText: this movie is great i am writing this review for the dvd version i own a copy on vhs but was happy when i was able to get this with the commentary on it i always love to hear from the actors who made such superb works of art. this is a true work of art Tobe hopper is a great film director  i remember going to see this movie when i was young my mom has always regreted taking us to see this when we were kids. i remember growing up we lived in elkhart indiana on friday nights mom would make pizzas and we would eat and take off to see the movie at the local drive-in then i believe you could watch at least 2 movies we had a station wagon so we had beds made up in back it was fun. i am so happy that we were able to catch this prize winner at the drive-in experience this movie has been talked about for nearly thirty something years do yourself a favor buy this movie. there are not a whole lot of drive-ins left but you can sure find a copy of this gem. thanks donnie p.s. reviewText: Simply put, one of the best horror movies of all time.This film works on so many different levels that it takes more than one or two viewings to understand them all.  You have the documentary look, the occult angle, the disturbing noises and camera angles ... it's all there and more.This film also marked the turning point in America horror cinema.  It was the first to take the fairy tale trappings of all the other horror movies and annihilate them.  In fact, the film's gleefully nihilistic feel steered the course of cutting edge horror films for years to come, though no film would come close to capturing this film's spirit.If all you know of is the sad, pointless remake, well, you need to see this.  It's just as disturbing today as it was all those years ago, too.

reviewText: This film is a low-budget masterpiece.  On its face, its a simple retelling of Homer's Odyssey with Odysseus recast as Sally Hardesty, who embarks on a journey with her crew to verify the sanctity of her grandfather's final resting place after reports of ghoulish desecration hit the news.Sally and her crew are lost the moment the pick up a hitchhiker, who replaces the Siren.  Then they stop at Cerce's gas station where they are further delayed by the Old Man/Cerce who tells them he has no gas but offers them barbecue, a clear reference to the pigs Odysseus' men where turned into.Instead of waiting for the gas delivery, Sally and her crew go to visit her ancestral home.  Two of her crew decide to go for a swim in the old watering hole but when they find the hole has dried up, they stumble upon Cyclops' lair where they embark on a doomed mission to trade a guitar for the much needed gasoline.This is really where the movie kicks into high gear, as one by one Sally's crew is disposed of by Leatherface/Cyclops.I first saw this movie on VHS in the '80's, after first seeing TCM 2, and I think I must have seen a copy that was cut to shreds because this movie is way better now then I remember it being back then.  There isn't as much gore as one would expect, but the ultra-violence really ratchets up the old adrenaline.The movie on the DVD looks great and its loaded with deleted scenes, bloopers, script excerpts, commentary, etc. etc.  The one thing that would have really made this a five star package is if it had been bundled with the 1988 documentary.As it is, I would rate both the film and the DVD 4.5 stars each.

reviewText: (this review refers to the Texas Chainsaw Massacre Ultimate Edition only)This is the second "special edition" of TCM. The first was more or less cash grab by Pioneer around the time the TCM remake hit theatres. It offered a "restored and remastered" picture and soundtrack plus all new special features. It did have a few extra special features added to it from the original no-frills version, but everything else was the same.Well, another TCM movie hit theatres recently, this time a prequel, and yet again another special edition dvd for the original hit store shelves. I bought the dvd due to a favorable review in fangoria and was pleasantly surprised. If you've seen the movie before you know how good it is and that it really deserves a good special edition release. It's easily one of the best horror films ever made and quite possibly the greatest slasher film of all time.In this edition the picture has never looked better. It offers a new high definition transfer from the original 16mm camera originals. Gone is the grainy, pixilated, washed out transfer and in it's place is a vibrant, colorful, beautiful version of the film. The greens of the trees and grass and the blues of the sky nearly jump off the screen, while the interiors are dark and brooding, but sharp and clear. And in the last scene, you've never seen a more beautiful sunrise in your life. The sound is also improved. A new stereo surround soundtrack is available and it's crisp and clear. I've never noticed how great the soundtrack is until now. In some scenes it's loud and wrentching, and in others it's low and droning, providing a deep sense of dread.How about those special features? well, i haven't gotten through them all yet, but suffice it to say that they needed another disc for all the special features they decided to cram in here. There's all the special features of the last special edition (a blooper reel, radio and tv spots, the original trailer, deleted scenes, a still gallery, and an informative and entertaining commentary with director Tobe Hooper, cinematographer Daniel Pearl, and Leatherface himself, Gunner Hansen), but this time around they added much more including two documentaries titled "Fleshwounds" and "Texas Chainsaw Massacre: The Shocking Truth", as well as a tour of the original TCM house (which is now a restaurant, believe it or not) plus outtakes from the documentaries, and a brand new commentary with the actors and art director Robert A. Burns, all packaged in a really cool tin case.This is the definitive version of the film that defined a genre and helped start a new one. You're not going to find a better version of the film and there are so many special features it'll take you hours to sift through all of them. For fans of the film, you can toss your old copies because this is the one that should be in your collection. As for new comers, get ready for a thrill ride like you've never expierenced before, because the Texas Chainsaw Massacre is back and better than ever.
summary: TCM Ultimate Edition: you can throw those other editions out!

reviewText: Lets face it horror when done properly is the modern tragedy. The razor thin line that seperates good horror from malicious, sadistic horror is whether one feels empathy with the characters whom suffer the tragic ordeals.The characters arent incredibly fleshed out but through the documentary style filming and the smalltalk they are emminently human.The violence in the film is few and far between however what is there is take your breath away shocking.This is where the excellent direction comes into play, Hooper takes the violence seriously and keeps his focus tight throughout allowing neither the audience or the actors to escape the reality and horror of the situations.Thats how horror movies should be, when people being murdered becomes either boring, dull or unintentionally funny, this is a great disservce to the audience IMO.As the film dips more into the insane universe of the cannibals it takes on a surreal experience rarely found in American horror.On balance the film is exploitive, afterall how can a film that revels in violence and murder not be, but the fact that it is possible to empathize with the characters saves it from slipping into the abyss. Still a very shocking film, that no developing person should watch! I cant believe parents let children watch this sort of stuff.P.s. The film was made about in a house in a town outside Austin called Round Rock about 15 minutes from where I live.
summary: Great Horror But More importantly Great Film!

reviewText: The Texas Chainsaw Massacre may not be one of my personal favorite horror films, but MAN is it good! This is the ultimate independent horror film that defined the slasher genre. You know the basic premise: it's about a psycho named Letherface and his chainsaw. It seems like a simple plot, but you should take a look at what he and his friends do with his victims. I won't spoil anything for you, but I will tell you that almost every horror fan adores this one. The scenario is simple but superior to those of more recent horror flicks: a group of young people need gas, so they search for some....and that's when the notorious Leatherface comes in. Gore is minimal, but take a look at all the bones! And the protagonists.....well, that's the only problem I have with this movie. The good guys/girls are very annoying. I couldn't care for them, especially Sally & Franklin Hardesty. When they get to the house where Leatherface dwells, these two cannot stop screaming and arguing. Franklin keeps talking, and Sally keeps screaming. Sally is much worse than Franklin, because all she does in the second half of the film is scream and scream and SCREAM! I know we're supposed to root for the protagonists, but honestly I was actually rooting for Leatherface rather than her. Fortunately, that's the only flaw in this movie. I had a really good time with The Texas Chainsaw Massacre. It's not one of my personal favorites, but I can still see why it's a cult classic all these years.Grade: B (due to the unlikable protagonists)
summary: Give this guy a chainsaw and you've got some serious mayhem!

reviewText: Despite its reputation for being an exploitational film with severed body parts and gallons of blood, THE TEXAS CHAINSAW MASSACRE is the horror classic that it is because it in fact leaves everything up to the viewer's vivid imagination. It just seems a great deal gorier than it really is.Without a doubt, however, it is an intense, grim, claustrophobic, and darkly comic shocker in which unwitting teenagers stuck in the Texas hinterland go into a deserted house looking for gasoline to put in their van. In that house, however, there is a notorious family of ghoulish cannibals, including the thoroughly deranged Leatherface (Gunnar Hansen), whose weapon of choice is not a hatchet or a knife, but a loud and whirring McCulloch chainsaw. Of the teens, only Sally (Marilyn Burns) will survive her horrific ordeal, and even then not with much of her sanity left.Based on the Ed Geinn story that also provided the inspiration for Hitchcock's PSYCHO, and perhaps even THE SILENCE OF THE LAMBS, THE TEXAS CHAINSAW MASSACRE is quite obviously a low-budget outing, made for something less than $300,000. But what he lacks in fiscal funding, director Tobe Hooper, who later went on to helm the 1982 thriller POLTERGEIST, more than makes up in sheer energy and almost unbearable, nightmarish suspense and tension. Often classified as a "meat movie" along the lines of NIGHT OF THE LIVING DEAD or THE LAST HOUSE ON THE LEFT, CHAINSAW actually seems like a much more ghoulish version of the equally brilliant 1972 shocker DELIVERANCE. Hooper's vivid camera work and the use of plastic props in place of severed arms and blood gives CHAINSAW its weird and throughly unsettling feel. The only really gory scene in this whole film involves Leatherface attaching one of the dead teens to a meathook. And except for the obvious amateurish acting of the teens, CHAINSAW distinguishes itself from most of the low budget horrors to come in its wake, including the much-debated 1999 flick THE BLAIR WITCH PROJECT.A "monstrous" hit when originally released in October 1974, thanks to all the attendant controversy it spawned, CHAINSAW is one of the most intense horror films around. The 'R' rating is there for a reason; the film is extremely disturbing and has explicit adult themes, so viewer discretion is strongly advised. But for those willing to take the chance, CHAINSAW is still literally a "cutting edge" horror classic.

reviewText: The original 1974 shocker film, The Texas Chainsaw Massacre, is everything that it's reputation says it is. This film was made by Tobe Hooper in 1974. Hooper set out to create a movie that would be the most shocking ever made for the big screen and IMHO, he succeeded. He produced, directed and co-wrote the film with Kim Henkel, who would later make another film entry in the series; Texas Chainsaw Massacre: The Next Generation (a.k.a.The Return of the Texas Chainsaw Massacre) a little over two decades later.The whole film starts with a narration by future Night Court star John Larroquette, which tells the story of what will happen in the film as we watch it. After the opening credits, we see five youths, three young men and two young women, taking a little cruise out in the countryside to check up on a grave where the Hardesty siblings grandfather is buried to see if it had been tampered with as in the area, there was a rash of grave diggings and grave robberies done by a mysterious suspect, with whom the police don't know who or why they are doing this sort of thing. The main youths Sally Hardesty (Marilyn Burns) and her invalid brother Franklin (Paul Partain; may he rest in peace) are conversing with the other youths in their van and talking about numerous things as they are on their way to an old shack out in the countryside on a hill. Along the way, they complain about the intense heat and humidity and even notice the smell of the old slaughterhouse where cattle are sold and slaughtered for meat to sell to consumers. Along the way, they pick up a freaky looking hitchhiker(Edwin Neal), who later proves to be part of their undoing as he causes trouble for the youths in the van, which ends with him slaughtering Franklin's wrist with a straight razor and being thrown out of the van because of that, and he leaves a marking of blood on the van and that is where the story really starts to unfold. After stopping at a service station and finding out that they have no gas, the man who owns the service station (Jim Siedow; may he also rest in peace), gives them some fresh barbecue and they head out to the old shack and later find out about the blood smeared on the van earlier by the hitchhiker. The rest of the youths check out the old shack and Franklin gets disgusted with being left alone while they check everything out.It is then that the story starts to get interesting as Kirk(William Vail)and Pam(Teri McMinn) decide to head to the old creek to go swimming only to see that the old creek has dried up since the last time that the Hardesty siblings were there. They stumble upon an old isolated farmhouse and after Kirk goes in, he gets hit with a sledgehammer by Leatherface(Gunnar Hansen) and after twitching, he gets hit again and Leatherface slams the kitchen up with a metal door. Pam, getting suspicious as to why Kirk doesn't come back out, she enters the house and after seeing all the furniture made with human bones and a lot of feathers all across the floor, proceeds to run out, only to be stopped by Leatherface and hung up on a hook and while screaming in pain, she watches as Leatherface cuts up Kirk with a chainsaw. Later on, Jerry(Allen Danzinger)gets concerned and decides to go out and look for Kirk and Pam, only to also stumble upon the old isolated farmhouse, enters the house and heads for the kitchen, where out of curiosity, he opens up the freezer and sees Pam in it and she is still alive as she raises her hands in fear, and looks partially frozen, and in comes Leatherface with his sledgehammer attempting to hit Jerry with it, which he misses slightly, but Jerry narrowly and successfully escapes with his life and disappears mysteriously as we never see Jerry again for the rest of the film.Later on, as it is getting dark, the Hardesty siblings are concerned and worried about their friends and think of looking for them, but are also undecided if they should because they don't want to leave the van alone in case the others come back. When the night is starting to get closer, they start calling out the names of their friends, but hear nothing. They proceed to look for them in the woods only to come across an angry Leatherface who slashes Franklin with his chainsaw and begins chasing Sally all over the place with the chainsaw with the determination of killing her and using her body for food for his demented cannibalistic family. The chase takes them to the farmhouse, then back outside in the woods and ending at the very service station they stopped at earlier in the film, only instead of getting protection and possibly getting the police involved, she learns that the service station owner, who is known as "the cook" in the family, is related to both Leatherface and the hitchhiker that they picked up earlier. Unbeknown to Sally, this is the start of an unforgettable night of unimaginable horror as both Leatherface and the hitchhiker taunt and abuse her relentlessly and although the cook says that he takes no pleasure in killing, he really contradicts this when he smiles later on when they continue to taunt and verbally abuse Sally, scaring her and motivates her begging the cook to make it stop. It turns out that Leatherface, whose facial mask is made out of crude human flesh, is looking for a new face and wants Sally's face as his new face. Will Sally escape the torturous family's house?, or, Will she be a feast for this demented family? As usual, I won't give too much away as I don't want top spoil this for anyone who hasn't seen this intensely shocking and horrific motion picture as of yet.This film was released in 1974 with the publicity that it was based on an actual crime that happened in Texas in August of 1973. It was only 1/8th true. The film and it's main protagonist, Leatherface, was actually loosely based on the story of Plainfield, Wisconsin murderer Ed Gein (a.k.a. The Ghoul of Plainfield) who also robbed graves and also killed people, particularly elderly looking women, for pleasure. Gein also came from an abusive home life as his mother, a legalistic styled so called Christian lady, repeatedly abused him and forbid him from having any contact with the outside world and after she died, his whole personal world came crashing down on him and he would later become an unholy terror in his hometown that he would be locked away in a mental institution for the rest of his life until his death in 1984 of respiratory failure. The rest of the film is basically the pure invention of Tobe Hooper and his co-screenwriter Kim Henkel. Hooper also revealed that he was mostly inspired to create this horrific motion picture by seeing a display of chainsaws in a hardware store and the idea to create a movie about a homicidal maniac with an equally homicidal family to boot came at him in a split second. He and Henkel wrote the script and started casting immediately. The whole thing started in 1972 and was finished within a year and ready for release. Again, Hooper decided to play the publicity that it was actually based on an actual crime, though most of the film's story was fictional. This even had an impact later on as to this day, many college and university students who major in psychiatry, psychology, criminal law and even law enforcement still visit the Texas State Police to ask for any files on this crime, only to be told repeatedly by the Texas State Police that the story really never happened and that it was all a publicity stunt by the filmmakers to shock the daylights out of people seeing the movie and really scare the daylights out of them.The film received mixed reviews upon it's original release in 1974, but over the years, it has been reappraised by many critics when they discovered the film's hidden greatness. Rex Reed even called this film "The Most Horrifying Motion Picture I Have Ever Seen!" I have to agree with Mr. Reed here regarding this particular film as it is horrifying and really scary. IMHO, this is the scariest motion picture ever made. Tobe Hooper, when making this film, really overdid it with the realism that he was trying to convey with this film and it worked. The film really carries you over the edge of your seat and really grabs you and refuses to let you go until the bitter end. Not only that, each and every prop that Hooper uses in this film looks like the real thing and that is what contributes to the horror factors making this a truly scary motion picture that continues to shock no matter how many times it is watched. It's ability to continue to horrify audiences repeatedly remains intact that at one private screening, the viewers walked out of the theater in a state of shock. I have watched this film repeatedly myself over the years and it still scares the daylights out of me. I have never had any motion picture in the horror genre do that to me until I saw this one. I remember seeing The Exorcist and while that movie scared me as well, it doesn't come close to this film. Many people claim that The Exorcist is the scariest motion picture ever made, but IMHO, The Texas Chainsaw Massacre is the scariest motion picture ever made with The Exorcist ranking a close second to it. This is scary and then some. The film is also a cult classic and is widely hailed as a masterpiece of modern horror and has also been highly influential.This film passed through a few distributors over the years since it's initial 1974 release. The first was Bryanston, which was an independent distributor of pornographic films and was later passed on to New Line Cinema, who took over distribution. When the home video market took off in the 1980's, the film passed through a few more distributors with Media Home Entertainment initially releasing this on home video and later, MPI Home Video continued it's home video run and when DVD's became the wave of the future, Pioneer released the film with a few special features added to it and finally, this special edition steel box release by Dark Sky Films, which has the film looking more colorful, increasing the terrifying factors that this film is known for, with various special features, such as commentaries, theatrical trailers, TV spots, radio spots, two documentaries: Texas Chainsaw Massacre: The Shocking Truth and Flesh Wounds: A tour of the house in the film with Gunnar Hansen leading the way and deleted scenes, outtakes and bloopers and a still gallery. Regarding sound options, you have a choice of three, such as Dolby 5.1, 2.0 Stereo Surround and Original Mono, with subtitles in English and Spanish.This film also has it's share of controversy as it was banned in several countries initially, mainly due to it's subject matter and it's overdone realism. In the wake of the film, it has spawned three sequels, a 2003 re-imagining, a 2006 prequel and a much recent 3D re-imagining of the film. It has also inspired copycat films where the main protagonist also uses a chainsaw in their murderous ways.Unless you have a strong stomach, I suggest that you don't watch this film as you definitely need a strong stomach to watch this particular film. If you do decide to give this film a try, I will caution you that you will be in for the most horrifying ride of your life as there has nothing been made like this before or after that will scare the daylights out of you, shock you, and also will grab you and won't let you go until the bitter end. Also, if you do decide to watch this film, don't ever say that you weren't warned ahead of time. It is truly a scary film and it is very horrifying and sure to leave you with chills that you will never forget.Overall, this original 1974 film is, IMHO, the scariest motion picture ever made and if you are a fan of the horror genre, it is well worth a look, but first make sure that you have a strong stomach before you even think of watching this film. I highly recommend this film to horror fans all over. It is a movie experience that you will never forget as it will leave an impact as well an impression on you that no other film has ever left before or after. It is scary and yes, it is horrifying, and yes, it is a shocker of epic proportions.
summary: It's Everything It's Reputation Says It Is

reviewText: Before I get to my own review (one of more than 580), let me just say that self referential movies and remakes are good for the core audience (anyone that can name Jessica Biel's other movies or anyone that's watched a boatload of the old WB), but as far as which movie is better?  I can't really answer that. If Hollywood Greenlights a remake, it's automatically given a bigger budget and more creative liberties.  Meaning Leatherface (or anyone else) can have a totally different backstory.  He can be an uneducated lummox or a backwoods Dr. Lecter; it's the screenwriter's (and ultimately the director's) call. This is good for characterization.  What I am getting at is there's no real need for an "E! True Hollywood Story" setup for a good character.  What's scarier?  Not knowing why someone's clubbing you over the head; or knowing that due to a crackwhore mother, and a life in "Da Hood", a person is going to start laying a smackdown on people?  Not seeing the gun laying bullets into the wall next to you?  Or seeing a gothic teen listening to Disturbed and Mudvayne (two bands I do like, believe it or not) loading up his dad's 30-06?Lots of blood doesn't necessarily mean scarier.  I've seen really scholcky B- or C-grade movies with tons of strawberry syrup and stage blood, and it still wasn't scary.Finally, before I get off my pedestal; why is the remake better?  Depending on your own judgment.  If it's because Jessica Beil showed a midriff and a lowriff and highriff and the hitchhiker blew her brains out with a gun she got from an unmentionable area....AND the creepy no teeth Sherrif...ok.  That's your opinion.  If you need tons of expositional dialogue and gallons of blood to be shed on camera before you get scared, then, oh dear reader, I have some movies for you.The Ed Gein references you have read about in earlier posts are in part true.  Ed Gein was a messed up Wisconsin resident that went over the deep end after his mother died.  He loved his mom a lot, even though she was extremely overbearing(enter Norman Bates' motivation).  He started making objects out of human skin (lampshades) and even sewed together some human masks to wear around the house (the reason for Leatherface's moniker).  He didn't have a chainsaw, was a total packrat, and was a loner.As far as the acting; it's not an award winner by any means.  Nor was it meant to be.Consider this.  How annoying was Luke Skywalker when he whined about picking up power converters?  Wasn't the entire movie bad acting?  Wasn't the dialogue poor?  Even Sir Alec Guiness suggested the series had "frightful(ly) rubbish" for dialogue.This is a movie that was made to be if not scary, than to be as creepy as possible.  The Marilyn Burns Scream-a-Thon (is it me, or does that whole dinner table scene seem too Corman for its own good?) was written to be how people would really act.  Ask any witness or victim of attack.  Do they throw a punch and recite some trite comeback?  Or do they go insane with fear?I can tell you one thing.  For the people that are still on the fence about this movie; look around your DVD collection now.  Is it missing some key horror movies?  Exorcist, Chainsaw, Wicker Man, and Night of The Living Dead are essential.Get the best of the 60s and 70s horror; then you can decide if the new Millenium's crop is worth dropping some coin on.

reviewText: This is a poignant plea on behalf of the rural unemployed, downsized by an indifferent capitalist society and what happens to them when they are left to fend for themselves. The film focuses on an ordinary family forced to carry on with what they know the best way they can when the local slaughterhouse is closed and they are thrown out of work. One son is forced to scrape a desperate living taking photos of tourists and selling them for a few bucks. His overtures are cruelly rebuffed by some privileged youngsters. Turning to sculpture as a means of expressing himself and his frustrations, he is met with opposition from local law enforcement who do not appreciate his efforts. A little used gas station is not enough to pay for furniture so the family are forced to make their own, as well as clothing and even lampshades. The head of the house hold also has to handle another son who is often left on his own in the house during the day. Damaging the door makes things even more difficult for the struggling family who are forced into cannabalism just to survive. In a desperate cry for help they kidnap a young girl, but her privileged middle class background will not allow her to accept their poor table manners and she selfishly flees without helping, despite all the boy's pitiful attempts to communicate his anguish and convince her to stay. When America becomes the Marxist United States, this sort of thing will not happen.
summary: Moving near documentary on rural poverty

reviewText: I bought this classic film when I was in the army about two years ago. Me and my friend thought it was a comic slasher piece with unintentionally hilairous gore and unfocused ravaging. We put it in to the TV lobby video recorder with smiles on our faces... This is going to be fun! Well, the smiles faded away right from the eerie beginning text. This clearly wasn't what we were expecting it to be! It is so sad that this film seems to be eternally plagued by it's unjust reputatiuon as a "dirty" low-budget horror turkey, when it is quite simply the most effective hooror film I personally have ever seen in my life. There's barely any gore ore blood to be seen. Instead, the film focuses on the pressing atmosphere that doesn't allow the viewer to be careless towards it. That is if the viewer is truely focused on watching the film. The film is clearly shot cheap, but the style only adds to the almost documentarily realistic sense of the film. Another thing that makes the film so effective is the fact that you don't get to emphatize with the villains, you don't understand them. That way you are left with a little less information than the victims and therefore empathize with them, becoming them. There are no explanations, no reasons for the horrid acts, only sheer terror. But the film also displays parts of inventive dark humor, mainly in the form of the family grandpa. The Texas Chain Saw Massacre is almost perfectly executed. Only real life (like the case of Ed Gein, the inspiration of the film shows) can be more horrific.
summary: ...And I thought it was a joke...

reviewText: Though these things are difficult to determine with any real accuracy, one gets the impression that 'The Texas Chainsaw Massacre' is the most important horror movie of the modern era.  'Night of the Living Dead' broke away from tradition, making a darker more graphic film, but it was 'The Texas Chainsaw Massacre' that really defined the path that horror would follow for the last quarter of the 20th century.  Of course, influential films may be good, or they may just be influential.  Fortunately, 'The Texas Chainsaw Massacre' is very good, easily topping virtually every film that it influenced, and is definitely worthy of it's classic status.Although this film isn't truly a slasher film, the basic plot is the same as a thousand of those films: 5 young people and stranded in a remote area, and terrorized and murdered by a psychopath/s.  The end.  Of course, 'The Texas Chainsaw Massacre' is different in terms of execution, lacking the clichés and graphic violence of such films.  And it's a helluva lot better.This film was plenty cheap, perhaps under $100,000 according to some reports, but it's technically at least competent on all fronts.  Other than Marilyn Burns, who is quite good, the principal victims are all competent, if not much more than that, and none of them are hideously obnoxious and loathsome.(Well, Franklin's pretty damn annoying,  but I didn't hate him)  The murderous family tends to be pretty over the top, but one would expect a family of murderous cannibals to be fairly eccentric.  I think the Hitchhiker takes it a bit too far in some scenes, and he's too jittery, his speech too stuttered, but this is a fairly minor concern.  Hansen is great as Leatherface, though It's primarily just physical size and the way he looks.  The film is capably shot, though it generally doesn't draw attention to itself, as the film is supposed to be stark and grimy.  The set-design is quite excellent, with their ruined old house and all of Leatherface's gross little trinkets.Though lotsa people fail to mention this, this film has actually got a lot of dark humor in it.  TCM is unique, in that it manages to integrate humor into the narrative without it seeming like deliberate comic relief.  It's just part of the story.  It also manages to be kinda funny, and unsettling at the same time, best exemplified by the climatic dinner scene, where the family's odd bickering is vaguely amusing, contrasting with Burns' endless, very convincing screaming and crying and whatnot.  It's a pretty powerful effect.In most ways, TCM is just a good horror movie, but it's got a bunch of little touches and specific details that really push it into the all-time great realm.  I can't come up with a way to describe this in a sweeping manner, so I guess I'll just resort to listing (SPOILER ALERT for the whole next section):  The opening scene is extremely creepy:  It consists of complete darkness, punctuated sporadically by the flash of a camera revealing ancient, desecrated corpses.  This scene also illustrates the power of the soundtrack, a minimalistic, melody free collage of metallic, shrieking sounds.  The first murder is an all-time great, easily one of the starkest and most brutal I've seen.  Leatherface just suddenly appears in a doorway, and clubs the guy with his hammer.  He goes down like he just had an anvil dropped on his head.  His hideous spasming and the way that Leatherface slams the steel sliding door are both very effective too.  Just a brilliant scene, though it only lasts a few seconds.  Marilyn Burns' performance is a huge asset as well.  'Scream Queen' is a stupid, generic term, but it really applies here.  Lotsa films like to focus on the death and the killer, forgetting that portraying the terror of the victim is one of the best ways to truly disturb the audience.  Finally, when Marilyn's character leaps out the window at the end of the film, and it's revealed that it's morning again, and that she's been there all night, well, that's just a really striking moment.  I dunno why exactly.As many have said by now, this film is not gory at all.  This isn't a concern for me, though occasionally the way that the death's are portrayed is a bit problematic.  People love to talk about how this 'suggests' violence, but I think that this is where the film fails, occasionally.  Simply put, the times when Leatherface actually takes a chainsaw to someone, it's conspicuously obvious that nothing is happening, and that he's just waving the chainsaw in their general vicinity.  But, this is only a minor concern.Yeah, I'm done.  Classic movie here.Grade: A

reviewText: Surprised I'm reviewing this? I'm not one to watch horror flicks.  This was pure horror, not porror.  This movie is indeed very suspenseful.  It is about a twisted cannibalistic family that has nothing better to do than make barbeques out of human remains.  The story begins when Sally, her wheelchair-bound brother (Franklin), and friends, Curt, Pam and Jerry set out to a cemetery to see if their grandpa's grave is still intact.  It seems someone is graverobbing and taking corpses out of their cripts in this small Texas town.  Grandpa's grave was okay, so the five young people went to see Sally and Franklin's dad's abandon house.  You can almost guess the horror about to happen.  We are introduced to an array of characters.  There is a hitchiker that put new meaning to the word weird.  Leatherface and his chainsaw getting the bodies ready for barbecuing.  The cook slapping his sons into shape. I was never bored!  This movie kept me in suspense and I was on the edge of my seat the whole time.  Was I scared?  NO!  There were parts that even made me laugh---When demented family brought grandpa down to let him have a "little fun".  This film definitely had me entertained.  I actually enjoyed this film!  I don't call myself a horror buff, but this flick is a definite buy for any movie goer.
summary: Grandpa, quit sucking on my finger......

reviewText: This is as terrifying as you've heard.  Whether you saw it on an old, faded VHS copy, or you saw it in the theater when it came out, or on a later, remasted edition, it is so relentless and claustrophobic that it is impossible to shed from your mind.  The thing about this film that despite its reputation, it has hardly any gore in it.  It is not a gorehound film, not even close.  It runs along the lines of Night of the Living Dead, an independent horror film that is truly scary and disturbing.  It's not a film in which you get a few scares and then some comic relief.  It's a plain nightmare of a film, and even in the end when one of the captives escape, you're still scared like hell.  It burns into your subconscious like only a handful of films do (Cannibal Holocaust, Night of the Living Dead, and Salo for example).  It's a testament to the filmmaker, Tobe Hooper, for making such a great film that still can scare people today.  Forget the sequels or the remakes:  this is the only one you need to see.
summary: Not a gorefest, but a real celluloid nightmare...

reviewText: When it comes to the film itself, what's to say?  It's a classic.  Horror films today just don't compare.  It's just one of those films that gives you that awful feeling in the pit of your stomach, without having gallons and gallons of blood and violence like the so called horror films of today.  You might be a vegetarian for a while after seeing this.There are some great things on here that make it a real "special edition."  It has some great extras, especially the commentary.  It's nice to listen along and hear about their ideas and things that happened on the set while you actually see them happening.  The bloopers are quite humorous.  Overall just a great DVD.  One of the better "special editions" of films out there. Had I known that it would eventually be worth so much, I probably would have never opened it.
summary: Great film with great extras.  Definitely worth it.

reviewText: I have to say when I first heard of The Texas Chainsaw Massacre I didn't know what to think. I heard so many people talk about how disturbing it was. So, being a huge fan of horror movies, I had to see what the hype was about. I was not disappointed. Like The Exorcist The Texas Chainsaw Massacre is not really scary as in jumping out of your seat and screaming, but is eerie and just plain creepy. These movies scare me most of all. Maybe it's the fact that the story is based on the true crimes of Ed Gein or maybe it's fact that this could actually happen almost anywhere in the world. The movie spills plenty of teenage blood and has multiple disturbing images that you won't soon forget. Tobe Hooper did a great job with this film on a low budget. Even though you can tell they didn't spend millions of dollars on special effects it takes nothing away from the movie itself and shows how far a great director can go. If you want a movie that will shock, scare and disturb you, you have to see The Texas Chainsaw Massacre.
summary: Creepy, Gorey, and Disturbing. A TRUE CLASSIC!!

reviewText: I cannot express how much I love this film. Well, I'll try. I first saw this with a few buddies, on a big screen TV, in the basement around the age of 13. Although the movie never really scared me, I would describe this film as one of the creepiest films ever. I believe it's banned in Germany and England. For a low Budget movie, this is an A+. The only one equal would be the first evil dead. It was Tobe Hooper's 3rd or 4th film and sadly he hasn't made one that has topped this one since. People also have to consider that this came out in 1974 and was the first of its kind. (I'm sorry but as much as I love it, Psycho is NOT a slasher Film) People walked out of the trailers of TCM in shock. I like the Idea that it's based on a true story, but it really isn't. Leatherface is somewhat based on the serial killer Ed Gein. Buffalo Bill from Silence of the lambs and Norman Bates are also based on him. And to put it bluntly, ED GEIN NEVER OWNED A CHAINSAW!!!!!! But back to the movie.The Plot: I think the best way to describe the film is to tell what is said in the short description in my TV guide (this movie is rarely ever shown on premium channels).Young Teens encounter a Houseful of demented Butchers who chase them with chainsaws and other deadly tools. It is Rated 3 out of 4 stars With a Highly recommended sign.Now to the average person, this may sound like a piece of crap that would appear on svengoolie. But its much more then that. It's best to just see the film; it would take forever for me to explain. This film is also one of the most creative movies I have ever seen; you will know when you see the furniture. I'm not surprised that people became vegetarians after watching this. (like the Director of Blade 2) Yes there is cannibalism. And as for the acting, the "family" is great, truly psychotic. The only thing that bugged me was that the hitchhiker was never given a name, in the credits he is just labeled hitchhiker. The 5 teenagers are the problem, some people complain that there isn't enough character development, I agree and disagree with this. These are supposed to be your average 70's teens who just want to have a fun time, no, not Friday the 13th nudity=death crap. There is no nudity. But back to the actors. The actress who played Sally is fantastic at being afraid. Her eyes are all I can say. Franklin (wheelchair guy) was supposed to be annoying to everyone else, and this succeeds in a few levels. The other 3 are where the characters need development. During the car trip we can tell that Pam likes the supernatural-sun-horoscopes things, which is cool. Some People belive that Activity with the Sun affects the behavior of living creatures or something like that. Her boyfriend seems like he would be a jock if he were at school. It's Jerry (Sally's boyfriend) who has almost no character development. In the car scene with the hitchhiker, he is simply the driver and never says a thing. Now one of the things that makes TCM, TCM are the sound effects. They are Creepy as hell. The score is absolutely brilliant, Wheather it's pots clanging together, camera flashes or just weird noises in general, Its great.DVD features: Ok first off, this has a blooper reel, some of them are really funny, but it is not long enough. Where is the one where the guy playing Jerry ran out of the room? For those of you who don't know, that guy wanted to be scared when Leatherface came in and killed him, he never saw the mask or costume before. So what ended up happening is when Leatherace walks in the room he screams and runs out the room scared sh*tless.The commentary features Tobe Hooper(Director)And Gunner Hanson (Leatherface)and Daniel Pearl (Director of Photgraphy). If you're a fan of this film it's really entertaining and a little funny. The deleted scenes were for good reason, the film quality sucks. They probably decided not to use them before redoing it with better quality stuff, its expensive you know. And as for all the other features; they are great, simply put.In Conclusion if you are tired of the overrated Jason, Michael, or Freddy. Pick this one out at your local video store or better yet, buy it, it will make its mark into your brain. The thing about this film back in 1974 is that something like this could really happen. Leatherface is not invincible like Jason, Mike and Freddy; He is just a strong inbreed-retarded-cannibalistic-butcher. A Guy at my school (yes I'm 16) Rented it and got up to the 2nd kill before turning it off, finding himself disgusted. Now if you thought that was bad I also tried to show it to a friend of mine at midnight. He never made it to the first kill; he got nauseous from the hitchhiker doing what he likes. BUY THIS MOVIE TODAY!!!!!!P.S. There is also not much blood, I think they only used something like one Can. it's all in your Head People.

reviewText: Simply put, "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre" is one of the most horrifying, intimidating, and ground-breaking horror films ever made. A group of young adults travel to an old family home to make sure that their deceased grandparents' graves have not been tampered with.  Unfortunately for them, they encounter a cannabalistic family deep in the woods who shred their victims with chainsaws, sledgehammers, or any other weapons they can find.  This film introduces the infamous Leatherface, a saw-wielding murderer who actually has a mask of human flesh.  Director Tobe Hooper does a masterful job of using what little budget he was given (which actually adds to the effect of the film) and uses his own gut-wrenching musical score to add a nice sinister touch.  Absolutely riveting for its time and still extremely intense today, "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre" will leave viewers breathless and covered with goosebumps.  Director:  Tobe Hooper.  Cast:  Marilyn Burns, Gunnar Hansen, Edwin Neal.  Rated R for extreme violence, gore, and profanity.  83 minutes.

reviewText: First of, I am a huge fan of this movie. I love it. Ok, now for the review. I will not be reviewing the actual movie, but I will be taking a look at the dvd edition called "2 disc ultimate edition".Right from the title, it states "Ultimiate" I have seen 3 disc editions sold in the UK. So that would lead me to belive that there are more versions out there, well, with more stuff. In america thoe, it is probably the best we are going to see for a while. First thing you will notice with this DVD edition is the case. The case is a fantastic "steal book". I love the quality and the art on the front of the case is beautiful. Actualy, if you have not see the film, the cover of the DVD case is a scene from the movie. Although I hope you do see this film for it is simply amazing and a piece of art. The inside of the case bosts an actualy, rare picture directly from the film. I have never seen this particular angled shot any other time while watching the film. A deleted scene perhapse? also bolth the outside cover and inside cover are washed out, it has this almost "dirty" yello color, bu this color realy works and seems to fir the movie quality all around.Now on to the features of the DVD. You will have trailers, and another bonus is the T.V. spots and radio spots. unlike other DVD realeses of films, not many come with the radio and T.V. spot's which to me is a pretty nice addition. I cant remember for sure, but I believe you also get a slide show of diffrent poster art work and advertisment posters, and some foreign art work. Mind you, the feautures are almost "spread" onto bolth discs, its not like there are only special features on disc 2. You will still get some on disc 1 but I cant remember specifically which disc holds which feature.There very interesting featurettes on how the film was made, how it was making it, and some insight on what some of the actors/actreses hade expirenced on set. I think you will be suprised at what these people went through to get this movie going. Trust me, now that I understand what they went through I appreciate this movie more than I used to.Note: I am listing the special features from memory, so if I miss some you understand why. There are also trailers for other films. Like I said I dont remember all the features, so I will end it here cause I cant remember all of them.Sorry if you feel like I left you hinging. I am also getting sorta annoyed by the fact that I said "feature" so many time lol.Overall, amazing DVD. Like I said there are probably better editions out there, but for America, this might actualy be the ultimate edition we have been waiting for. Plus the price is amazing for this DVD, I payed $5.00 for this at wallmart brand new! amazing price I am very happy with it.
summary: Fantastic edition, amazing feautures and awesome movie!

reviewText: Tobe Hooper's classic masterpiece known as "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre", aka "TCM" (the original version) is quite simply one of the greatest horror movies ever made.  Made in 1974, "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre" continues to frighten and horrify viewers, who are brave enough to watch and endure its horror, to this very day!!  Interestingly enough, the simplicity of the story of "TCM" is astonishing when considering its lasting effect on horror movie audiences and the horror genre itself.  The story of "TCM" is horrifying enough to the viewer, but the way that the story is presented to the audience accentuates the horror and dread that the audience experiences to the utmost degree.  Tobe Hooper presents "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre" to the audience with a sense of horror with a brilliant style as well as a truly terrifying subject matter, both which create a truly horrifying experience for the audience.  Hence, this is the essence of a pure horror movie, to scare and frighten and not just to shock and disturb."The Texas Chainsaw Massacre" is a movie about a group of young adults (in their early to mid 20s) who take a summer's day drive during the heat of the August sun in the heart of the slaughterhouse region in Texas.  The movie starts out with our young adults which include the invalid Franklin, his sister Sally, Jerry, Curt, and Pam on their way to Sally's and Franklin's father's unoccupied house out in the middle of nowhere to have a fun summer's day.  What ensues from this point forward is a horrifying ordeal that goes beyond the imaginations of ordinary people like Sally and Franklin.Perhaps what is so amazing about "TCM" is its simplicity and realism.  In fact, it wouldn't be that farfetched in today's world to find people just like the villains in "TCM".  Clearly, this is one aspect of "TCM" that absolutely terrifies the viewer, the idea that this could happen to you if you find yourself in the wrong place at the wrong time and around the wrong people.  Just like the cook in "TCM" said, "you don't want to go foolin' around other folk's property, some folks don't like it, and they don't mind showin' you!". Of course, those of us that have seen "TCM" know that the horror of "TCM" goes much deeper than that.  It seems that Leatherface and his friends have a taste for beef, and they are not that discriminatory about how they get it if you know what I mean and I think you do (to borrow the great Joe Bob Briggs' patented phrase)!The horror of "TCM" is so intense when it hits you that it's not uncommon for some folks to get sick in the stomach before they finish this film.  I remember when I first watched it I was waiting for my Mom's favorite country style steak dish to be cooked, but after I watched "TCM", I wasn't that hungry if you know what I mean.  Indeed, "TCM" is gross folks, and it could sicken you to your stomach, and it's not gore we're talking about here; it's the kind of disgusting and horrifying people that our young unsuspecting adults unfortunately run into.  They are disgusting individuals, and the sad and scary thing about it is that there are really people like this out there, maybe not just like (although I would not be surprised if there were people just like this in today's world) Leatherface, the Cook, the Hitchiker and Grandpa, but of the same malignant nature and ill mind.  Clearly, the sadistic, malignant, and evil nature of the villains in the original "TCM" transcend just about anything you will ever see in a horror movie and I've just about seen them all, and I say that because of the joy these guys took in terrorizing, torturing and murdering their victims.  Just watch the way these monsters act with Sally and see what I mean...ghastly!!!The realism of the way "TCM" is executed is a superb horror movie device as the viewer will notice that much of the killing occurs in broad daylight dispelling some of the horror movie cliches that the seasoned horror movie viewer is so accustomed to.  "TCM" truly catches the viewer off guard with the way in which the movie unfolds.  The audience becomes shocked at the brutality, savagery, and yet horrifying way in which the killings occur.  However, aside from the brutality and savagery involved, "TCM" is also a scary movie as it produces a terrifying atmosphere conducive to cinematic horror and a sense of dread, fear and suspense about what is going to happen next which is essential to a horror movie's effectiveness.The setting of "TCM" is truly outstanding.  The detail in "TCM" is amazing considering its low budget and simplicity.  The houses look scary, everything is placed in the perfect location like the tooth on the porch, the bones, the cans in the trees, the chicken in the cage, etc. etc.  "TCM" isn't effective just because a crazy person saws people up with a chainsaw (if you want to see that, just watch the comical "Pieces"), but "TCM" is a work of art, a virtuouso that paints a horrifying picture and plays a terrifying tune of horror, a piece of art that is pure terror at its finest that captures the audience and drives the horror home to the viewer with its sense of evil, malignancy, brutality, and realism.  The acting in "TCM" is second to none.  The actors who play the hitchhiker, the cook, Leatherface, Franklin and the cemetery drunk are absolutely perfect in every conceivable way!!  Also, the story of "TCM" itself provides the audience with a realistic portrayal of horrifying events that strike at the very heart of the viewer's consciousness.  Moreover, the music in "TCM" is also quite effective in producing the appropriate mood, motifs, and themes at the precise moment so that the movie is able to produce the maximum fear effect in the audience out of each horrifying scene.  "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre" garners HorrorMan's highest recommendation, and this movie is a classic and must-own piece of horror cinema that helps create the crux of any true horror movie collection.In "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre", Tobe Hooper creates one of the most horrifying movie experiences ever made, and one of the greatest and scariest horror movies of all-time in the original "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre".  Truly, there have been many pale imitations, but there has never been anything quite like the original "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre" and there won't be either.  In fact, I don't think it is an overstatement to say that the original "TCM" paved the way for many subsequent horror movies as well.As a side note, I have seen the remake of "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre", and while I did honestly find it to be entertaining (and rather amusing at times as well), it is absolutely NOTHING compared to the original.  As a final note, I should point out that the original "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre" is VERY LOOSELY based or perhaps I should say that the idea for this movie is derivative from the twisted and sadistic life of Ed Gein, a disgusting killer from the State of Wisconsin from many years ago.If you have not seen the original "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre", then you are missing something my friend.  Go buy the original right now, sit down (without any food whatsoever) and watch one of the most horrifying movies ever made, but just don't blame me if you get sick with horror after seeing it, and I say that with all of HorrorMan's sincerest affections of course. :)
summary: "My family's always been in meat." -The Hitchhiker

reviewText: (There may be some spoilers here so beware.)Honestly, I thought it was a joke. I really didn't think this was seriously the movie everyone raved about. It's TERRIBLE! I mean it's really, REALLY bad. How on earth ANYBODY could enjoy this film is far beyond my vast, vast, incredibly vast understanding. It so bad you cannot even laugh AT it.First of all the film's so called 'gritty' look is, plain and simple, the result of the shoddiest photography this side of 70's [adult films]. The framing is horrifically composed and makes a drunken wedding video look like Laurence of Arabia. The sound is inaudible and the dialogue, worthless as it is, is nothing more than mumbles. As the 'story' develops so does the incomprehension. Mid-way through you'll tell yourself 'This cannot become anymore senseless.' Well it does. By the end you'll be completely lost and then...it's over. Just like that. I was assuming there was half an hour left but it just ends without resolving anything or giving us the payoff we deserve. What a rip-off!There is also ZERO suspense. Characters are killed almost right away leaving no room for excitement. Plus there is only ONE massacre with a chainsaw and you don't even see anything and it mostly occurs off camera. The final chase with the one character that actually gets some interaction with the bad guy is obviously the best bit of the movie but by this point I just wanted it to be over.I've no idea why so many people say this is a great movie or call it 'horror with a dark comic edge'. It's nothing of the sort. It's an embarrassingly amateur schlockfest that Ed Wood himself would disown. Check out the 2003 remake which is a zillion times the movie this dreadful nonsense is. Do not come within a mile of this! You have been warned.
